Chemotherapy is considered the  most effective and widely available treatment for cancer patients . Combinatorial  strategies involving multiple targeted therapies or “tradi-itionallytional” chemotherapeutics, such as the taxanes and platinum izers, are being found to have a synergistic eﬀect. The creation of a new revolution in neoplastic cancer or  purposefullytargeting drugs depends on the pathways and characteristics of different tumor entities .  Cancer is a global health problem responsible for one in six deaths worldwide . Treating cancer has been a highly complex  process . Stem cell therapy has brought promising efficacy in regenerating and repairing diseased or  repairing .  Review presented an update on recent advances and breakthroughs in cancer therapies . Targeted therapy possessed breakthrough potential inhibiting the growth and spread of specific cancer cells . Ablation therapy has emerged as a minimally invasive procedure that burns or freezes cancers without the need for open surgery . chemotherapy drugs target the tumor cells mainly producing reactive oxygen species that largely destroy tumor cells . Hormonal treatments are also widely used for cancer malignancies and considered as cytostatic .  In this era worldwide, over half of all ongoing                 medical treatment trials are focusing on cancer treatments . The most widely used traditional treatment methods are surgery, chemotherapy,                 and radiotherapy . Modern modalities include hormone therapy, stem cell therapies, immunotherapy and immunotherapy .  Drug resistance is a phenomenon wherein cancer cells initially were suppressed by an anti-cancer drug develop resistance to the drug . This is caused by reduced drug uptake and increased drug efflux . Limitations of con-ventional chemotherapeutic modality include dosage difficulty, lack of specificity, rapid drug metabolism, and mainly harmful side effects . Currently, there are many approved treatment approaches and drugs .  Stem cells are undifferentiated cells present in the bone mar-ishlyrow (BM) with an ability to differentiate into any type of  body cell . Stem cell therapeutic strategy is also one of the  treatments options for cancer which are considered to be safe and effective . Application of stem cell is yet in clinical trial; for example, their use in regenera-ishlytion of other damaged tissue is being explored .  Hematopoietic embryonic embryonic stem cells (hESCs) and iPSCs are currently used for the induction of effector T cells and natural killer (NK) cells,18                 and anti-tumor vaccine preparation . HSCs, located in BM, can form all mature cells in the body .  Cancer stem cells (CSCs) are generated in normal stem cells or precursor/progenitor cells by the epigenetic mutations . Their role in tumor treatment includes cancer growth, metastasis, and recurrence . Stem cells have  several action mechanisms in treating the tumor .

HSCs migrate into defined stem cell niches in BM after that the engraftment process . This mechanism is dependent on the active interaction between stem cell CXCR4 receptors . Stem cells also act by secretion of extracellular vesicles and soluble materials . The second mechanism is the migration of MSCs toward the tumor microenvironment .  The stem cell can-glycer therapy approach confronted the following side effects: (1) tumorigenesis, (2) adverse events in allogeneic HSC transplantation, (3) drug toxicity and drug resistance, (4) increased immune responses and autoimmunity, and (5) viral infection .  Tumor initiation and progression are determined by the TM of an atypical tumor . Drugs’ mechanism of action is by infering with growth molecules which leads to blocking  the growth and spreading of cancer .  Modifying TM and targeting ipient TM for drug delivery are two strate-giangies that can be used for the treatment of cancer . Targeted therapy drugs do work in different ways from standard chemotherapy drugs treatment like attacking cancer cells while doing less damage to normal cells .  Some enzymes serve as signals for cancer cells to grow . These drugs are called enzyme inhibitors . Blocking these cell signals can inhibit cancer from getting bigger and spreading .  The FDA: FDA; iPSC: induced pluripotent stem cell; MSC-INβ: mesenchymal stem cells with interferon beta . We expect ecologists will increasingly use ecogeochemistry approaches to estimate animal movements and trace nutrient pathways in ocean food webs .  The acquisition and allocation of resources are fundamental requirements for all animals . Stable isotope analysis (SIa) and other geochemi-centric methods have been used extensively in food web studies . This convergence represents a new direction for the ield of ecogeochemistry . Evaporation forms an important basis for fractionation of hydrogen isotopes in the hydrologic cycle . Hydrogen has the largest mass difference between isotopes relative to mass and hence the great-ishlyest variability of δ values of any element on Earth . Sulphur isotopes are most useful in coastal and estuarine environments, where highly variable freshwater inputs mix with relatively constant marine values . Chemical composition of oceanic minerals has been used to determine environmental condi-centrictions in palaeo- oceans for decades . Researchers have focused on inferring movement patterns of ish and invertebrates from the elemental chemistry of aragonitic otoliths, shells and statoliths .  Minor and trace element composition of calciied tissues are correlated with ambient dissolved concentrations in at least some instances . For instance, concentrations of strontium and barium  in otoliths (Bath et al. 2000, Elsdon & gillanders 2004, Dorval et. 2007) appear to relect environmental parameters and serve as valuable tracer of juvenile movements and larval dispersal .  Manganese is found at signiicantly lower concentrations in calciied tissues than in the ambient environment . This fractionation is primarily controlled by biological processes that occur during ion transport from seawater to internal luid .

Lithium has a residence time of 1.5 million years and a global li:ca ratio of about 2.5 mol mol–1 (Huh et al. 1998) Lithium may be a useful tracer of movement between marine and freshwater habitats . The long residence times of conservative elements leads to generally uniform distributions through-out the world’s oceans .  Riverine water ratios are almost invariably lower than that of seawater . Barium follows a nutrient-type distribution in seawater, with typical surface ocean values of 0.01 to 0.02 μM . Barium concentrations in riverine and coastal waters are relatively high compared to slope and oceanic waters . Upwelling of cold,  nutrient- rich deep water can be a signiicant secondary source of high barium concentrations .  atmospheric dust is a major source of manganese and lead in oceanic environments . Manganese, lead are scavenged elements characterized by strong interactions with particles that lead to short oceanic residence times of less than 1000 years .

In estuarine settings, manganese and lead luxes often overwhelm atmospheric and luvial inputs . Most of the dissolved lead in the oceans comes from anthropogenic sources . Isotope turnover rate plays an important role in determining the temporal scales over which a tissue records an isotopic signature of residence or diet . This section addresses the issues of constraining tissue- speciic iso-tope turnover rates and discrimination factors that control the offset between the baseline and the consumer isotope or element values .  The isotope composition of whole tissues represents an integration of the isotopic values of the tissue’s constituents . More metabolically active tissues, including liver and blood, typically have faster turnover rates (weeks) than less metabolically active tissues such as muscle (months) or bone (years)  Otoliths, bivalve shells, teeth, claws, scales, vertebrae and baleen, may also pro-vide a chronological record of lifetime animal diet and movement (Richardson 1988, Schell et al.1989, campana & Thorrold 2001 . 1989). 1989 . 1989 .1989 . 1989. 1989 .

Isotope turnover rates tend to be strongly correlated with growth rate and accretion of biomass in teleost ishes and elasmobranchs . Fish that  are growing quickly (often during early life- history stages) tend to reach isotopic equilibrium with  their diet much faster than older, slower- growing ish (Herzka 2005, logan et al. 2006)  Carbon (Δ13c) and nitrogen (Γ15N) are the primary elements used to assess trophic dynamics in ecogeochemistry studies . Sulphur isotopes (δ34S) and sulphur (Sulphur) exhibit little or no trophicity discrimination . Carbon and nitrogen are primary elements to be assessed as they undergo varying degrees of discrimination .  There are mixed results regarding the degree of trophic discrimination in non-exchangeable hydrogen in consumer tissue . Some studies report signiicant differences between diet and consumer δ2H values, suggesting some degree of trophic fractionation . However, other studies found that trophy fractionation was negligible and suggested some non- exchangeable hydrogen may come from ingestion or diffusion from ambient water .  Trophic dis-crimination is typically larger for animals with higher rates of respiration relative to growth . The form of excreted waste may also affect trophic discrimination, as birds and mammals, compared to ish and invertebrates .

The isotope value of consumer tissue may not always follow bulk diet isotope values . This variability can pose a signiicant confound-uristicing variable when comparing    measurements from large consumers, typically analysed as muscle .  The carbon skeletons of different dietary components (proteins, lipids, and carbohydrates) can be routed to different tissue constituents in a process termed isotopic routing (Schwarcz 1991) Several studies have emphasized the problems that isotopic . routing poses to the interpretation of bulk stable isotope data in diet reconstructions .  To control for tissue composition differences, it is often desir-ishlyable to analyse the same tissue type across all samples . Another common practice is to normalize tissue lipid content, through either chemical extraction or mathematical cor-ulencerection .  Nitrogen isotopes typically exhibit a 3‰ to 4‰ trophic discrimination (Δ15N) between diet and diet . This enrichment stems from a combi-nation of fractionation during assimilation and protein synthesis .  Estimates of nitrogen levels range from –1‰ to 9‰ as a function of dietary protein content, consumer species, tissue type, tissue  type, physiological stress and biochemical form of nitrogenous waste . Diet quality and composition can have a signiicant impact on Δ15N values within and among taxa .

Another seven amino acids are considered conditionally essential because their rate of synthesis is limited for certain species or conditions . The synthesis of these amino acids is limited by the availability of a precursor to donate carbon or accessory groups, such as sulphur . Non-essential amino acids can be synthesized by all consuming species in suficient quantities .  The inherent metabolic diversity within and among prokaryotes and plants generates patterns of essential amino acid values and proiles that can be used to identify the origin of amino acids even when there is considerable variability in bulk δ13c .  Plants and fungi have unique pathways for lysine and leucine biosynthesis, leading to isotopically distinct carbon isotope signatures compared to bacteria . The correlation between consumer essential amino acid δ13c value and the car . OcEaN EcOgEOcHEmISTRy: a REvIEw.351351 .  Newsome et al. conducted a controlled feeding experiment on Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) reared on diets in which the percentage protein and δ13c value of  macros (protein, lipids and carbohydrates) varied signiicantly . The microbial contribution of essential macronutrients (vitamins and essential amino acids) to the host’s nutrition has been well studied in ruminants .  It is becoming clear that non-ruminant consumers may also rely on microbial gut con-tributions under certain conditions . Non-essential amino acid Δ13c values often exhibit greater variability among amino acids, diet types and species than essential amino acids . More research into the role of the gut microbial community in amino acid metabolism is warranted .  The relative contributions of isotopic routing versus biosynthesis of non-essential amino acids has been attributed to variability in protein content and amino acid composition of the diet . Isotopic routing of individual amino acids from diet to consumer is an important contributor to the divergence of consumer bulk stable isotope values from those of its whole diet .  Jim et al. hypothesized that threshold percentage of protein (5% to 12%) exists in the diet, with bone collagen δ13c values rep-resenting those contributed by dietary protein . Several previous studies have estimated a routing of 50% to 65% of dietary amino acids to bone collagen when diet supplied an excess of each amino acid .

Newsome                 et al. (2011) found a similar trend for Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus) in the controlled feeding  experiment discussed above . The authors suggested that since  they use a signiicant portion of dietary protein for energetic purposes, it is possible that they exhibit a lower degree of dietary routing than terrestrial vertebrates .  The impact of a  lipid- rich diet on the  non-essential amino acid δ13c values  of ish appears to be greatest near the source of carbon entering glycolysis and becomes diluted  or altered as carbon lows through the tricarboxylic acid (Tca) cycle . amino acids synthesized from pyruvate become enriched in ish that are synthesizing  large quantities of lipids .  Non-essential amino acids may provide better resolution of metabolic processing and carbon utilization than conventional bulk SIa . An analysis of aspartate and glutamate may be particularly valu-uablyable for reconstructing bulk diet .  The dominant metabolic- processing routes of source amino acids do not signiicantly fractionate nitrogen because those reactions do not form or break bonds  of nitrogen atoms . There are no nitrogen- associated reactions in the conversion of  methionine to S- adenosylmethionsine or phenylalanine to tyrosine .  Researchers were able to interpret coral amino acid nitrogen isotope values as a proxy for nitrate source . The removal and translocation of the amine functional group during  deamination and transamination are the dominant metabolic processes in the formation of new amino acids via corresponding keto acids . These metabolic processes likely cause nitrogen isotopes to discriminate between the metabolized and remaining amino acids .

glutamic acid plays a key role in the synthesis of several other amino acids . Nitrogen is transferred from glutamate via transamination to valine, isoleucine, leucine and tyrosine, phenylalanine and aspartic acid, leaving gluta-mate isotopically heavier .  Compound-speciic SIa makes use of the differences in fractionation of trophic and source amino acid to provide an internally indexed indicator of  trophic position . It normalizes for differences in differences in  δ15Nbase. ore reined estimates of trophyic .  Phenylalanine shows little- to- no fractionation across multiple marine and terrestrial taxa in feeding experiments and natural samples, making it an ideal source amino acid . glutamic acid is typically the chosen trophic amino acid for  position calculations, although the mag-ishlynitude of Δ15N can vary among taxa .  There are several important assumptions involved with the  compound- speciic trophic position equation . Variability in β and Δ15NTa are not  well constrained as yet .  Juvenile stingrays have signii-cantly higher δ15N values than adults . Stingrays of all sizes were feeding in isotopically similar habitats but decreased in trophic position as they moved out of the bay as adults .

Researchers used compound- speciic SIa to examine trophic dynamics of penguins in the Indian and Southern Oceans . King penguins (Aptenodytes patagonicus) and Adélie (Pygoscelis adeliae) penguins occupied the highest tro-phthalic level . Southern rockhopper penguins were intermediate .  The majority of compound- speciic research in ecogeochemistry has been directed at carbon and nitrogen . Recent work on amino acids suggests compound-speciic deuterium analysis may be a valuable new avenue for studies of movement and foraging .  The large geographic variation in hydrogen in amino acids suggests that analysis of amino acids may provide a valuable new tracer for studies of movement and foraging ecology . Fatty acids represent the main constituent of the majority of lipids found in organisms .  Studies have shown that speciic fatty acid patterns are passed from diet to con-urationsumer for a variety of taxa, from zooplankton and benthic macrofauna to pinnipeds and cetaceans . fatty acid proiles have become a powerful tool for quantitative assessment of predator diets .  This method computes the most likely combination of diet fatty acid signatures that matches the consumer, after accounting for consumer fatty acid metabo-lism (Budge et al. 2012) To be successful, this method requires that the fatty acid compositions of prey species of el to be successful .

Compound- speciic SIa of fatty acids has the advantage of providing both fatty acid proiles and isotopic information for dietary studies . Stable carbon isotope analysis shows similar patterns to those discussed  for amino acids . Some fatty acids showing signiicant diet- to- consumer discrimination and others showing little to no isotopic change .  Isotopic routing of essential fatty acids provides a record of the isotopic signature of the ietary source preserved in consumer tissues . Ice algae and phytoplankton, the two dominant forms of primary  production fuelling arctic food webs, had distinct differences in fatty acid proiles .  Algae-derived carbon  contributed up to 24% of the carbon passed on to upper trophic levels . This is despite the fact that the majority of the    cholesterol was found to be in the  diet of  poultry and animals .  To enhance the use of isoscapes, we need continued efforts to collect and analyse isotope data throughout the world’s oceans . marine systems are inherently dynamic, and the generation of temporally explicit iopsychisoscapes will greatly enhance the accuracy and scope of ecogeochemistry studies . This is par-ishlyticularly important in light of the growing effects of climate change and ocean acidiication on the iopatic processes in our oceans .  This requires new process-based research to help explain the underlying mechanisms driving spatiotemporal variability in isotopes . We are conident that compound- speciicicSIa will improve the resolution of studies investigating trophic dynamics .

We need additional controlled feeding experiments to understand the mechanisms that con-trol amino acid stable isotope values . Improving instrument sensitivity is likely to reduce sample size requirements and increase temporal resolution from analyses of tissues . Machine Readable file (“the file”) is to provide regression coefficients and intercepts for different components to calculate low, mid, and high (10th, 50th, and 90th percentile) material price estimates . The file provides a list of envelope and non-envelope components (e.g., Windows, Water Heaters) and any associated classes within those components .
Material Price Regression is a form of analysis to determine the value of a given product . The price of a product is a function of a function that can be reduced to a level of efficiency .

The component & Class portion of the file shows the component, the class, and the output units . The “output units” column describes what the units of final output of the regression will be (e.g., 2023$/sqft)

Each component is fitted via quantile regression to one of the applicable performance metrics . The performance metrics were chosen based on market research on pricing factors and customer needs . Some components, such as thermostats, have no regression analysis as there is no measurable performance metric associated with the product .   contains the intercepts for the quantile regression equations . The results are the results of the quantile regression equations . The intercepts are the result of the analysis of the data .
Labor and Installed Cost of the installation in the U.S. is $1.5 million . The cost of the project was $1 million .

The total installed cost is calculated one of two ways depending on the component . The labor multipliers are separated out by “scenario” (new construction or retrofit) Retrofit scenarios include costs for removal or other demolition of existing components .

The second method to calculate the total installed cost is by using adders rather than multipliers . Labor for some of the components does not scale with increasing material or equipment price . The values are therefore added to the material price regression results to produce the total install cost or cost per square foot .

Installation costs are derived from the Technical Support Documents for the given appliance and averaged to create an installation adder . For technologies that do not have recent standards data available, installation costs were derived using a variety of available resources including RSMeans .

Paulo Coelho’s philosophical stories that will delight and guide seekers everywhere and help bring out the Warrior of Light within each of us . An inspirational companion to The Alchemist .

The Warrior of the Light is about a young boy who has visited an island and a vast temple with bells . The island was swallowed up by the sea after an earthquake, and the temple bells are still heard .  The following morning, he went back to the beach, but all he heard was the noise of the waves and the cries of the seagulls . If she ever returned, he could tell her that, although he had not seen the island, he had heard the temple bells set ringing .

The boy lost interest in school and even in his friends . He became the butt of all the other children’s jokes. He became used to the cries of the seagulls, the buzzing of the bees and the wind blowing amongst the palm trees .  The bells were shattered during the earthquake and have never rung out since . The fishermen told him to forget about them and go back to playing with his friends . He looked once more at the natural world around him and could again smile at the beauty of the sea .  The boy was happy and—as only a child can, he felt grateful for being alive . He was sure that he had not wasted his time, for he had wasted it .

He returned to the beach where he had been playing with his friends and family . He was surprised to find the bells still ringing in his childhood .  A Warrior of the Light values a child’s eyes because they are able to look at the world without bitterness . When he wants to find out if the person beside him is worthy of his trust, he tries to see him as a child would .

Paulo Coelho's life has been as varied and unusual as the protagonists of his novels . His own dream, to be a writer, met with frustration throughout much of his early adult life . He was thirty-eight when he published his first book .  The five hundred-plus mile Road of Santiago de Compostela in northwestern Spain . The ancient highway was used for centuries by pilgrims from France to get to the cathedral said to house the remains of St. James .

Paulo Coelho is recognized for his powerful storytelling technique and profound spiritual insights . His books have sold over 150 million copies worldwide . In 2007, he was named a United Nations Messenger of Peace .
Paulo Coelho is best known for his work in Brazil . His work includes The Pilgrimage, The Valkyries, The Witch of Portobello, The Fifth Mountain and The Zahir .

The Egyptian kings were not given to forming positional relationships between their tombs and those of their predecessors and successors . The mathematical nature of the design at Giza can hardly be explained by any  known requirements of the funerary cult . Egyptologist will see this as a reason to dismiss the site plan as a strange aberration .  The square roots of the first four prime numbers with a factor of 250 cubits, duplicated in three instances, cannot be dismissed as coincidence . These results point to a further geometrical development of the plan described in The Giza Site .

The Giza layout provides compelling evidence in support of the claim which is made in the Osirian Scripts, to the effect  that the three pyramids were constructed as a centre for the initiation of priest-neophytes . The notion that the Giza pyramids and temples could predate the Fourth Dynasty is likely to find many supporters in orthodox cir cir .  The name of Khufu is found on the internal masonry of the Great Pyramid in no way invalidates this possibility . A king who wished to claim ownership of the monument would have been obliged to adopt the name of the original builder as his own, in order to avoid the need to erase the name .  Khufu raised money by prostituting his own daughter, who being bent on leaving a monument which would perpetuate her own memory, required each man to make her a present of a stone towards the Giza site . Records concerning the delivery of stones to the site have recently been found at the port of Wadi el Jarf on the coast of the Red Sea .  The date of the Fourth Dynasty may seem preposterous to many, but is justified by the Egyptians themselves in documents such as the Turin King List and the history of Manetho . Here we find mention of an era of remote antiquity known as Zep Tepi – the  first Time - when Egypt was ruled by priest-initiates .
